maya civilization was among the greatest
of the ancient new world their culture
endured the span of mesoamerican history
witnessing the rise and fall of
teotihuacan and surviving the expansion
of the later aztec empire when we think
of ancient maya sites the grandeur of
tikal or palenque comes to mind classic
period centers dominated by pyramids and
palaces now shrouded in jungle
but such regal cities were more often
located far from the sea
maya civilization was fueled by
agriculture and the more productive
lands were found well inland these areas
also offered better protection from
frequent hurricanes that would ravage
the coast
hence the massive maya centers of renown
are located not along what we perceive
as idyllic stretches of beach but rather
deep in the interior it was not until
certain social and economic push and
pull factors emerged that maya peoples
turned their attention to the sea
the yucatan peninsula where the
caribbean meets the gulf of mexico
ultimately bore witness witnessed one of
the greatest seafaring traditions of the
ancient new world maya traders once
plied these waters in massive dugout
canoes filled with goods from across
mesoamerica
each port was a link in a chain
connecting people and ideas and
supporting the ambitions of city and
state
but who were these ancient maya
seafarers
it is believed that long-distance
coastal trade was initially dominated by
the so-called putun maya of the gulf
lowlands
archaeologist j eric s thompson once
referred to these shrewd and intrepid
merchants as the phoenicians of the new
world
early accounts suggest that the maritime
maya saw themselves as more refined than
their inland contemporaries their
cosmopolitan and entrepreneurial
character shaped by interactions with
people and ideas from far away lands
even though most maya peoples who built
occupied and even presided over grand
centres like tikal never laid eyes upon
the sea and its wonders
they were nevertheless aware of this
mythical realm at the edge of their
known world
incised on bones found in the burial of
hasak on
tikal depict paddler deities on a
journey with the maze god
perhaps a representation of a celestial
event
for the maya the sea was truly
primordial along the watery edges of the
earth the sun descended into darkness
and was reborn each new day
the land of the yucatan was imagined as
a turtle floating on the sea
subject to its forces both benign and
malevolent
from the turquoise horizon of the
caribbean came the winds and the rains
of the approaching summer
sea creatures appear in maya art and
iconography and objects that capture the
essence of the sea like conch shells
stingray spines and coral were
incorporated into ritual practice and
can be found at sites across the maya
world
in the dresden codex we see chalk the
god of rain and lightning paddling a
canoe upon a flooded earth perhaps
bearing the headgear of the merchant god
known as god l
across the yucatan peninsula the
timeliness and abundance of seasonal
rains ensured a fruitful harvest thus
the maize god and water were tightly
bound together from the sowing of seeds
to the full life cycle of this essential
crop
on a polychrome vase from the whole mole
region of guatemala we see the maize god
delivering a sack of seed corn in a
canoe paddled by two deities
the concept of the sea and its mythical
power were pervasive and integral to
maya worldview and cosmovision
maritime trade and interaction on the
caribbean coast of the yucatan peninsula
reached its fluorescence on the eve of
spanish contact during the post-classic
period which began around ad 1100
the once bustling towns of shkadet and
shaman ha were the ports of embarkation
for cozumel one of the most important
pilgrimage destinations and centers of
commerce during the slate period
while accommodating a steady stream of
travelers and traders these sister
centers no doubt supported and were
supported by their near coastal
hinterlands which comprise one of the
most densely populated maritime cultural
landscapes in the maya area
to the south tonkan tulum dominated
post-classic coastal interaction
evident in the region's mural art is a
rich synthesis of broader mesoamerican
ideas and influences which speak to the
connectedness and multicultural fluency
of coastal peoples at this time
the maya of the northeastern corner of
the yucatan peninsula were faced with
extraordinarily complex and harsh
coastal environments which can be
characterized as a mosaic of non-arable
zones including mangrove estuary flooded
forest and sawgrass
these marginal areas were unfavorable
for maize agriculture which as we know
was the staple for ancient maya society
for this population to not only exist
but thrive in this adverse environment
they required highly specialized
subsistence strategies involving
perennial access to fresh water
exploitation of marine resources and
cultivation of niche plant species
we mentioned how the coastal maya
imagined themselves somehow different
from their inland neighbors
certainly life along the coast required
different skills
these maya people were fishers casting
nets for fishes and hunting the waters
for sharks rays turtles manatees even
the now extinct caribbean monk seal
the bottoms of bays and reefs were rich
in mollusks like massive whelks and
conks and crustaceans like crabs and
spiny lobster
iguanas crept along the rocky shore and
crocodiles lurked in the lagoons
such a different world than the
agricultural landscapes and managed
forests so far from the sea
the most important commodity produced by
the coastal maya was salt which we will
discuss in a later episode
maya ports were bustling in addition to
hunting gathering processing foodstuffs
resident support centers were busy
manufacturing and preparing both
pre-formed and finished goods for
transport as well as sheltering
provisioning and outfitting sea-going
traders who are constantly arriving and
departing in their long dugout canoes
in our next episode we will explore maya
seafaring
and search for evidence of these fabled
and elusive watercraft
